subject: Re: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)
msgSnippet: ... English speaker and I use nearly all of the sounds that Quickscript represents. I have been writing in Quickscript for about 8 years and I use it for about
messageBody:
---
> As a counterpoint to what's been said so far, I'm an American
English speaker and I use nearly all of the sounds that Quickscript
represents. I have been writing in Quickscript for about 8 years and
I use it for about %90 of my daily writing. Also I'm the person who
built and uploaded the quickscript dictionary here. It is a American
English dictionary and it surely uses all of the sounds. The "awe",
the "ah", ...
---

nearly all? Which ones do you not use?

I would also like to ask what defines whether you choose 32 or 34.
If it is the consonants surrounding it, then why bother with an extra
letter?

The a-vowel in "cAlm" and "whAt" both use the same letter and sound
quite similar in British English as near as I can tell, so why not
combine them as T.O. did?

Please also note that I'm not being argumentative here, I am merely
curious as to the need for two different letters for such similar
sounds.

nearly all?  Which ones do you not use?

I would also like to ask what defines whether you choose 32 or 34.  
If it is the consonants surrounding it, then why bother with an extra

The a-vowel in "cAlm" and "whAt" both use the same letter and sound

Please also note that I'm not being argumentative here, I am merely 
curious as to the need for two different letters for such similar 
sounds.
